H0.text: Resistors are metals that easily transfer electricity.

H1.text: Magnets are metals that easily transfer electricity.

H2.text: Insulators are metals that easily transfer electricity.

H3.text: Conductors are metals that easily transfer electricity.

A4.text: Insulators are non-conducting materials with few mobile charges that support only insignificant electric currents.

A5.text: Conduction materials include metals, electrolytes, superconductors, semiconductors, plasmas and some nonmetallic conductors such as graphite and conductive polymers.

A6.text: In metals, the Fermi level lies in the conduction band (see Band Theory, above) giving rise to free conduction electrons.

A7.text: Wood is widely regarded as an extremely good insulator, but its resistivity is sensitively dependent on moisture content, with damp wood being a factor of at least 1010 worse insulator than oven-dry.

A8.text: In metals there are many electron energy levels near the Fermi level, so there are many electrons available to move.

A9.text: Electrical conductivity (or specific conductance) is the reciprocal of electrical resistivity.
